questions.text: As a first-year derma resident, you see a pt with the following skin lesion. Which of the following disorders is LEAST likely to present in this form?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Basal Cell Carcinoma

 

Option D:

 

  • Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) is least likely to present in this form, as BCCs more commonly appear as pearly nodules with telangiectasia or as non-healing ulcers with rolled borders, rather than scaly plaques.
  • The image shows a Papulosquamous lesion. Basal Cell Carcinoma does not cause papulosquamous lesions.
  • Papulosquamous disorders are diseases that present with papules/plaque with scaling.
  • These conditions can be easily remembered with the Mnemonic TEN SLIPS.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC):

 

  • It can present as a variety of skin lesions, including plaques, ulcers, or hyperkeratotic lesions, often with a scaly surface.

 

Option B. Secondary Syphilis:

 

  • This can present with a wide array of cutaneous manifestations, including maculopapular rashes and scaly plaques.

 

Option C. Mycosis Fungoides:

 

  • It is a form of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, might present with patchy, plaque-like lesions that can be confused with eczema or psoriasis in their early stages.
  • They typically have a scaly surface.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When assessing a patient with a scaly skin lesion, Basal Cell Carcinoma is least likely among the options provided, as it typically presents with pearly nodules and rolled edges, rather than scaling plaques.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 35 Page No 35.9

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of extremely itchy lesions over his hands. On examination following cutaneous lesions are present over the body. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lichen Planus

 

Option A.

 

  • The skin lesion in the preceding image features the distinctive purple, flat, polygonal papules of lichen planus.
  • The five characteristics of lichen planus lesions are 5Ps: purple polygonal, pruritic, plane topped (flat), and papules.
  • Lichen planus has characteristics including cicatrizing alopecia, flat-topped purple polygonal papules, and plaques on the flexural aspect of the wrist, Wickham's striae on the lips, longitudinal ridging, and thinning of nails.
  • It commonly affects the wrists, forearms, and genitalia.

 

 

  • Lichen planus producing Cicatrizing/Scarring alopecia
  • In almost 30–70% of cases with lichen planus, mucous membrane lesions develop.
  • It primarily affects the anal and genital mucosa as well as the tongue and buccal mucosa.

 

 

 

  • Wickham's striae are distinctive white streaks that create a lacework in the buccal mucosa.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Psoriasis

 

  • It typically presents with well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scales, most often on extensor surfaces like elbows and knees, and may involve the scalp and nails.

 

Option C. Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris

 

  • It usually shows orange-red plaques with a characteristic "islands of sparing," and keratotic follicular papules, which are not as pruritic as lichen planus.

 

Option D. Pityriasis Rosea

 

  • It often begins with a single "herald patch," followed by a "Christmas tree" distribution of smaller lesions on the trunk, which are not typically as itchy as lichen planus.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When presented with pruritic, purple, polygonal papules, consider Lichen Planus as the most likely diagnosis, and differentiate it from other dermatoses like psoriasis, pityriasis rubra pilaris, and pityriasis rosea based on lesion morphology and distribution.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 2 Chapter 37 Page No 37.1

questions.text: In which of the following are Max Joseph Spaces characteristically seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lichen Planus

 

Option A.

 

  • Max Joseph spaces refer to areas of degeneration within the epidermis, specifically in the basal layer, which is a feature seen in lichen planus.

 

Lichen Planus

 

  • Lichen planus is characterised by the degeneration or destruction of basal epidermal cells. This degeneration leads to the formation of spaces in the epidermis known as Max Joseph spaces.
  • It happens as a result of dermal CD8 + T lymphocytes destroying basal keratinocytes.
  • Colloid bodies, also known as cytoid or Civatte bodies, are degenerating basal epidermal cells that can appear singly or in clusters.

 

Other histopathological characteristics of lichen planus include:

 

  • Hyperkeratosis, Hypergranulosis,
  • Pigment incontinence (melanin slowly migrates into the dermis as a result of keratinocyte degeneration), engulfment of dermal melanin by macrophages to form Melanophages (melanin-containing macrophages) and
  • The development of Max Joseph spaces in the epidermis.
  • There is a band-like lymphocytic infiltrate at the dermoepidermal junction; the rete ridges have a saw-toothed appearance because they are pointed at their lower ends.

 

The image below shows the HPE of Lichen planus with arrows pointing out Saw toothed appearance of Rete ridges:

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Psoriasis

 

  • It is characterized by Munro micro abscesses and regular acanthosis, not typically associated with Max Joseph spaces.

 

Option C. Pemphigus

 

  • This involves intra-epidermal blisters and acantholysis, especially seen in Pemphigus vulgaris, not Max Joseph spaces.

 

Option D. Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris

 

  • It shows follicular plugging and psoriasiform hyperplasia.
  • Max Joseph spaces are not a feature of this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Max Joseph spaces a is a histological feature of Lichen Planus, which is important for the microscopic diagnosis of this condition.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 37 Page No 37.14

questions.text: Characteristic Nail change of Lichen Planus among the given options?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pterygium

 

Option D.

 

  • The most distinctive nail change in lichen planus is a dorsal pterygium, which results from development of fibrous tissue with the fusion of the proximal nail fold and nail bed causing destruction of the nail matrix and ultimately resulting in nail loss or deformity.
  • Dorsal nail pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus.

 

 

  • Nail changes in Lichen planus
  • Up to 10% of Lichen planus cases can involve the nails, but this is usually a minor aspect of the condition.
  • Thinning of the nail plate is the most common nail change.
  • Pup tent sign – elevation of nail in shape of tent
  • Trachyonychia – 20 nail dystrophy

 

The image below shows thinning of nail plate (the Most common feature) & longitudinal striations & Trachyonychia –

 

 

  • Subungual hyperkeratosis & onycholysis
  • Longitudinal melanonychia in Lichen planus of the nail bed
     

Image shows Nails in lichen planus presented with irregular longitudinal grooves & ridges.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Longitudinal ridging of nails

 

  • This can be seen in a variety of conditions and is not specific to lichen planus. It is often a normal variant or associated with aging.

 

Longitudinal ridging & nail plate thinning

 

 

Option B. Anonychia

 

  • It is the absence of nails, can occur in severe cases of several conditions, but it is not characteristic of lichen planus specifically.

 

Anonychia:

 

 

Option C. The "Pup Tent" Sign

 

  • It is associated with lichen planus, but not characteristic to LP like pterygium.

 

Puptent sign:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pterygium is a distinctive nail change indicative of lichen planus, which can lead to nail dystrophy and requires differentiation from other nail abnormalities.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 37 Page No 37.12

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with subtle, fine, reticulate lacy white pattern in the buccal mucosa, flat topped pruritic purple papules and plaques limited to wrist. Most appropriate treatment strategy would be?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Topical Steroids

 

Option A.

 

  • The patient's age and the presence of reticulate lacy pattern in the mucosa, suggestive of Wickham striae and purple, polygonal flat-topped papules, and plaques on the wrist, all point to a diagnosis of lichen planus. 

  • Topical therapy would be sufficient, as the involvement is limited rather than extensive lesions.

 

Topical Steroids.

 

  • This is the first-line treatment for lichen planus, particularly for symptomatic relief of cutaneous and mucosal lesions and persistent lichen planus.

  • They help reduce inflammation and immune response, alleviating symptoms.

  • Systemic steroids, retinoids, and PUVA are used as second-line treatments.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Interferons

 

  • They are used in some chronic viral infections and certain malignancies, but are not the first-line treatment for lichen planus.

 

Option C. PUVA (Psoralen and Ultraviolet A)

 

  • PUVA therapy may be used in severe cases of lichen planus that are not responsive to topical therapies, but it is not typically first-line due to its side effects and the intensive nature of the treatment.

 

Option D. Methotrexate

 

  • It is a systemic immunosuppressant that might be used in severe, widespread, or refractory lichen planus, but it is not usually the first step in treatment due to potential side effects and the need for monitoring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a patient presenting with lichen planus affecting mucosal and cutaneous surfaces, topical steroids represent the cornerstone of initial treatment for their anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 37-Page No 37.16

choices.text: Islands of Sparing over Body

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the Derma OPD with thickened palms & Soles. These lesions were insidious in onset. He was diagnosed with Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris. Which of the following features is most likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Islands of Sparing Over Body

 

Option C.

 

Features of PRP:

 

  • Dry scaly plaques with salmon red or orange red colour are characteristically seen; these plaques coalesce to leave islands of normal skin, commonly referred to as islands of sparing, between the lesions.
  • Trunk: the most typical location.
  • The image below shows islands of sparing in pityriasis rubra pilaris.

 

 

  • Follicular hyperkeratosis causes nutmeg grater papules to appear on the elbow and wrist.
  • Palmoplantar keratoderma causes keratoderma on the sole to be so thick that it resembles a sandal.

 

 

  • Thickened, discoloured nails that are distally showing splinter haemorrhages.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Nail pitting

 

  • It is commonly seen in psoriasis, not typically in PRP.
  • While nail changes can occur in PRP, they are not as characteristic as the islands of sparing.

 

Option B. Pterygium

 

  • This is a finding more commonly associated with lichen planus and involves the progression of skin to encroach upon the nails, which is not a feature of PRP.

 

Option D. Herald patch

 

  • It is associated with Pityriasis Rosea, a different condition that presents with a large, solitary patch followed by a generalized body rash, not typically seen in PRP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Islands of sparing is a distinctive clinical sign in patients with Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris, which can aid in differentiating it from other erythrodermic skin diseases.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 36 Page No 36.1 – 36.4

 

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2783063/

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the collarette scale characteristically seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pityriasis Rosea

 

Option A. 

 

  • Collarette scale is a fine peripherally attached&centrally detached scale at the edge of an inflammatory lesion.

 

 

  • It is seen in Pityriasis Rosea. Acute self-limiting disease called pityriasis rosea primarily affects children and young adults.
  • A distinctive skin eruption and few constitutional symptoms define it.
  • It is connected to HHV 7 and 6 virus infection.

 

Some other diseases & special scales seen in them:

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Collarette scale is a hallmark of Pityriasis Rosea, which helps in differentiating it from other scaling skin conditions.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Page No 4.13, 25.91-25.92, 26.2, 29.15, 40.1-40.5, 50.6, 65.2, 107.3, 109.8

 

Andrew’s Diseases of the Skin: Clinical Dermatology – 11th Edition Chapter 11 Page No 200

 

Online resources:

https://ijdvl.com/scaly-signs-in-dermatology/

questions.text: Identify the phenomenon shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isomorphic Phenomenon

 

Option B.

 

Koebner or isomorphic phenomenon:

 

  • It is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin.
  • The new lesions have iso(same) &morphic (morphology) as existing lesions.
  • Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

 

 

  • The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

 

 

Some rare causes of true Koebner phenomenon are:

 

  • Darier's disease,
  • Hailey hailey disease,
  • EMF erythema multiforme,
  • Kaposi’s sarcoma &
  • lichen nitidus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Gottron papules:

 

  • They are associated with dermatomyositis and are characterized by raised, violaceous papules and plaques over the dorsal aspect of the knuckles.

 

Option C. Nikolsky sign:

 

  • It is a clinical sign where the skin shears off easily when rubbed and is typically seen in conditions like pemphigus vulgaris.
  • Nikolsky’s sign: On application of tangential pressure over skin on the border of an intact blister → upper layers of epidermis separate from the lower layers →→ skin peels off → extension of the blister.

                    → Erosion formed → Nikolsky’s sign.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Koebner phenomenon (Isomorphic phenomenon) is the development of new skin lesions on previously unaffected skin due to trauma in patients with certain predisposing skin conditions.

 

Ref: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 19th Edition Page No 347

 

Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 35 Page No 35.5

 

Online resources:

https://www.uptodate.com/contents/psoriasis-epidemiology-clinical-manifestations-and-diagnosis

https://www.researchgate.net/publication/6195226_The_isomorphic_phenomenon_of_Koebner

questions.text: A 29-year-old male presents with asymptomatic scaly lesions over body as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pityriasis Rosea

 

 

Option B.

 

  • This condition typically begins with a single, larger "herald patch" and then develops a widespread "Christmas tree" pattern of smaller lesions along skin cleavage lines on the trunk.
  • The lesions are oval with a fine scale and central clearing, which is characteristic of pityriasis rosea.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pityriasis Versicolor

 

  • It usually presents as hypopigmented, hyperpigmented, or erythematous patches with fine scale, predominantly on the upper trunk, neck, and arms, often with a variable response to sun exposure, making affected areas stand out more on tanned skin

 

 

Option C. Pityriasis Alba

 

  • It is commonly seen in children and presents as hypopigmented, slightly scaly patches, usually on the face, and is often associated with atopic dermatitis.

 

 

Option D. Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris

 

  • It typically presents with orange-red plaques with characteristic islands of sparing and palmoplantar keratoderma, which are not depicted in the provided image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The diagnosis of Pityriasis Rosea is supported by the presence of a "Christmas tree" distribution of scaly lesions on the trunk.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 25.90

 

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 170

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with violaceous plane-topped papules associated with Pruritus over the wrist and antecubital fossae for 2 months. The lesions have a characteristic shiny surface and are arranged in a linear pattern. What is the first line of treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Topical steroids

 

The description of violaceous, flat-topped, shiny papules in a linear arrangement and pruritus is characteristic of lichen planus, a chronic inflammatory skin condition. The first line of treatment for limited disease and for symptomatic relief, including pruritus, is high-potency topical steroids. These agents help to reduce inflammation and immune response in the skin.

 

Explanation:

Option A (Antifungals): Antifungal agents are not effective for lichen planus as it is not a fungal infection.

 

Option B (Oral steroids): Oral steroids may be used for severe, widespread, or refractory lichen planus but are not usually the first line of treatment due to the potential for systemic side effects.

 

Option D (Phototherapy): Phototherapy may be considered for widespread lichen planus or when topical treatment is not practical or effective, but it is not the first line of treatment.

 

Educational objective:

  • The first line of treatment for lichen planus, characterized by violaceous, flat-topped papules with pruritus, is high-potency topical steroids to reduce skin inflammation and pruritus.

 

Ref:  Books Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 37-Page No 37.16

questions.text: Match the papulosquamous disorders in Colum A with its characteristic feature in Colum B:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a

 

The correct matches:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Pityriasis rubra pilaris (1) with Palmoplantar keratoderma (b).

 

  • This condition is characterized by thickening of the skin on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet, and it is one of the distinguishing features of Pityriasis rubra pilaris.

 

 

Lichen planus (2) with Wickham's striae (c).

 

  • Wickham's striae are fine white lines visible on the surface of the papules seen in lichen planus, typically found in the oral mucosa but can also be seen in cutaneous lesions.

 

 

Pityriasis rosea (3) with Herald patch (A)

 

  • Pityriasis rosea often begins with a single, large, round or oval pink patch known as the herald patch.

 

The option "d Row of Tombstones" is recognized feature associated with pemphigus vulgaris.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Correctly matching Pityriasis rubra pilaris with Palmoplantar keratoderma, Lichen planus with Wickham's striae, and Pityriasis rosea with the Herald patch is crucial in the diagnosis of these papulosquamous disorders.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 25.90. 36.2, 37.4, 154.2

choices.text: The condition can be associated with Hepatitis C Infection.
Narrowband UVB Therapy is sometimes used in the management of this condition.
The scales characteristically have a Free Inner Edge.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the clinic with a 2-week history of a rash that started with a single, larger, scaly lesion on his trunk, followed by multiple smaller lesions. He reports mild itching. He denies any recent illness, medication changes, or high-risk behaviours. On examination, the smaller lesions are oval, with a collarette of scale and distributed along the lines of cleavage. Which of the following statements is INCORRECT regarding this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The condition can be associated with Hepatitis C Infection

 

Option A.

 

  • The association of Hepatitis C with this condition is incorrect. Hepatitis C has been associated with lichen planus but not classically with pityriasis rosea, which is what the patient's presentation suggests.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Narrowband UVB (NBUVB) therapy

 

  • It may be used for symptomatic relief in extensive or persistent cases of pityriasis rosea, though it is not commonly needed as the condition is usually self-limiting.

 

Option C. The description of the scales having a free inner edge

 

  • This refers to the characteristic scaling pattern seen in pityriasis rosea, where the scale is attached at the periphery and free in the center (Collarette scales).

 

Option D. Pityriasis rosea is typically a self-limiting condition

 

  • Pityriasis rosea is typically a self-limiting condition, resolving without treatment within 6-12 weeks to a few months.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pityriasis rosea is NOT associated with Hepatitis C infection, whereas it is typically self-limiting, may feature scales with a free inner edge, and only occasionally requires treatment with narrowband UVB therapy.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 25.90

 

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 170

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a widespread erythematous rash over his back characterized by fine scaling and distinct areas of unaffected skin, or "islands of sparing." Considering Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris (PRP) as a potential diagnosis, which of the following clinical signs would be most supportive of this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perifollicular Erythema

 

Option C.

 

  • Is a classic finding in PRP, often observed as a reddish halo around hair follicles on the affected areas and is one of the supportive signs of this diagnosis.

 

 

IMAGE: Orange–red follicular papules with coalescence into large scaly plaques, in addition to islands of sparing; follicular hyperkeratosis is often easier to appreciate within the relatively spared islands

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Keratoderma blenorrhagica

 

  • It is typically associated with reactive arthritis, not PRP, and presents with hyperkeratotic lesions on the palms and soles.

 

 

Option B. The Koebner phenomenon

 

  • This refers to the appearance of new skin lesions on the site of trauma and can be seen in various dermatologic conditions like psoriasis and lichen planus, but it is not specific to PRP.

 

Option D. Nail Pitting

 

  • It is commonly seen in psoriasis, and while nail changes can occur in PRP, they are not as diagnostic as perifollicular erythema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When evaluating a patient with a scaly erythematous rash and islands of sparing, identification of perifollicular erythema can support the diagnosis of Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris, a condition that requires a distinct approach to management compared to other papulosquamous diseases.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 36.2

 

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 166

questions.text: A 33-year-old female comes to the clinic complaining of severely itchy, purple-coloured lesions on her arms as shown in the image below. On physical examination, you note flat-topped papules with white lines on the surface. Given the clinical presentation, you suspect lichen planus. A skin biopsy is performed to confirm the diagnosis. Which characteristic feature is expected in the biopsy of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Basal Cell Degeneration

 

Option B.

 

  • Basal cell degeneration is the expected histopathological finding in a biopsy for lichen planus. This degeneration leads to the formation of Civatte bodies (apoptotic keratinocytes).

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hypogranulosis

 

  • It is typically seen in psoriasis, not lichen planus. Lichen planus is characterized by hypergranulosis, which is a thickening of the granular cell layer.

 

Option C. Pautrier's microabscesses

 

  • These are characteristic of mycosis fungoides, a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, and are not associated with lichen planus.

 

Option D. Munro's microabscesses

 

  • These are seen in psoriasis and consist of collections of neutrophils in the stratum corneum, not typical of lichen planus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When a patient presents with pruritic, purple, polygonal papules and white lines, expect to find basal cell degeneration on skin biopsy, supporting a diagnosis of lichen planus.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 37.4

 

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 199

questions.text: Match the Papulosquamous disorders in Column A with the characteristic scales they present within Column B:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a

 

Explanation:

 

 

 

 

 

Some other diseases & special scales seen in them:

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Page no 4.13, 25.91-25.92, 26.2, 29.15, 40.1-40.5, 50.6, 65.2, 107.3, 109.8

 

Andrew’s diseases of the Skin: Clinical Dermatology – 11th Edition Chapter 11 Page No 200

 

Online Resources:

https://ijdvl.com/scaly-signs-in-dermatology/

questions.text: Reverse Koebner phenomenon is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Psoriasis

 

Option C.

 

  • The Reverse Koebner Phenomenon refers to the clearance of skin lesions following injury or trauma to the area.
  • It is not commonly described in the medical literature but has been observed in certain cases.

 

Koebner or Isomorphic Phenomenon:

 

  • It is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin.
  • The new lesions have iso(same) &morphic (morphology) as existing lesions.

 

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

 

 

  • The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

 

 

Some rare causes of true Koebner phenomenon are:

 

  • Darier's disease,
  • Hailey hailey disease,
  • EMF erythema multiforme,
  • Kaposi’s sarcoma &
  • lichen nitidus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The reverse Koebner phenomenon, where skin lesions may clear following trauma, has been observed in some cases of psoriasis.
  • This is contrary to the more commonly recognized Koebner phenomenon where new lesions appear at sites of injury.

 

Ref: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 19th Edition Page No 347

 

Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 35 Page No 35.5

 

Online resources:

https://www.uptodate.com/contents/psoriasis-epidemiology-clinical-manifestations-and-diagnosis

https://www.researchgate.net/publication/6195226_The_isomorphic_phenomenon_of_Koebner

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with a recent history of an upper respiratory tract infection now presents with multiple erythematous, annular lesions featuring a collarette of scale on the trunk. The lesions are neither pruritic nor painful. Based on the history and clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pityriasis Rosea

 

Option C.

 

  • It often begins with a herald patch followed by a "Christmas tree" pattern of annular lesions with peripheral scaling.

 

 

  • It is usually self-limited and can follow a viral illness, which fits the presentation in this case.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lichen planus

 

  • It is characterized by pruritic, purple, polygonal papules, and it commonly presents with Wickham's striae.

 

 

  • It does not typically follow an upper respiratory tract infection and is not usually annular or scaling in presentation.

 

Option B. Seborrheic Dermatitis

 

  • This often presents with greasy scales and erythematous lesions, typically in areas rich in sebaceous glands such as the scalp, face, and upper trunk.

 

 

  • It is more common in infants and adults and tends to be chronic.

 

Option D. Tinea Versicolor

 

  • It is a fungal infection that causes hypo- or hyperpigmented macules with fine scaling, primarily on the upper trunk, neck, and arms.
  • The lesions can be mildly pruritic but are not typically annular or associated with recent infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pityriasis rosea is a self-limited condition commonly preceded by an upper respiratory tract infection and presenting with characteristic annular lesions with a collarette of scale on the trunk, which can be distinguished from other dermatoses like lichen planus, seborrheic dermatitis, and tinea versicolor.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 37.6

 

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 170

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents with a distinctive rash. Based on a comprehensive assessment, a diagnosis of Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris (PRP) is established. Which of the following clinical features is least likely to be associated with PRP and instead may suggest an alternative diagnosis such as psoriasis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Arthropathy

 

Option D. 

  • Arthropathy, or joint involvement, is not a typical feature of PRP but is commonly seen in psoriasis, particularly psoriatic arthritis.

 

Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris:

  • It shows Equal Sex Incidence.
  • Treatment of Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris :

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Orange red skin plaques

  • Orange-red plaques are a hallmark of PRP, characterized by their distinctive coloration which helps differentiate PRP from other dermatological conditions like psoriasis..

 

Option B. The Islands of Sparing

  • It is a feature that can be seen in PRP, contrasting with the more uniform involvement in Psoriasis. 

 

Option C. Keratoderma,

  • Keratoderma or thickening of the palms and soles, is a hallmark of PRP and can help differentiate it from psoriasis, although palmoplantar involvement can occur in both conditions. 

 

Explanation:

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Understand that arthropathy is not typically associated with pityriasis rubra pilaris and may indicate psoriasis, especially when considering the potential diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis. 

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 35.44

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 166

questions.text: Pityriasis Rosea is a self-limiting condition. How long does it usually last from the time of onset?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Correct. Pityriasis rosea generally lasts about 6 weeks, although it can sometimes take longer, up to 8-12 weeks, before the lesions fully resolve.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pityriasis rosea is a self-limiting condition that typically resolves within 6 weeks from onset, without the need for treatment.

 

Ref: Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 170

questions.text: Which of the following features are NOT associated with the condition shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Munro Micro Abscesses

 

Lichen planus:

 

  • The patient's age and the presence of purple, polygonal flat-topped papules, and plaques on the flexural aspect of wrist as shown in the image points to the diagnosis of lichen planus.
  • Munro micro abscesses (Collection of Neutrophils in stratum corneum) are not a feature of Lichen Planus but they are seen in Psoriasis.
  • Lichen planus (LP) is an idiopathic inflammatory disease affecting the skin and mucous membrane.
  • The five characteristics of lichen planus lesions are 5Ps: purple polygonal, pruritic, plane topped (flat), and papules.
  • Lichen planus has characteristics including cicatrizing alopecia, flat-topped purple polygonal papules, and plaques on the flexural aspect of the wrist, Wickham's striae on the lips, longitudinal ridging, and thinning of nails.
  • Wickham's striae are distinctive white streaks that create a lacework in the buccal mucosa.

 

 

 

 

 

  • Lichen planus ischaracterized by the degeneration or destruction of basal epidermal cells. This degeneration leads to the formation of spaces in the epidermis known as Max Joseph spaces.
  • It happens as a result of dermal CD8 + T lymphocytes destroying basal keratinocytes. Colloid bodies, also known ascytoid or Civatte bodies, are degenerating basal epidermal cells that can appear singly or in clusters.

 

Other histopathological characteristics of lichen planus include:

 

  • Hyperkeratosis, Hypergranulosis
  • Pigment incontinence (melanin slowly migrates into the dermis as a result of keratinocyte degeneration), engulfment of dermal melanin by macrophages to form Melanophages (melanin-containing macrophages) and
  • The development of Max Joseph spaces in the epidermis.
  • There is a band-like lymphocytic infiltrate at the dermoepidermal junction; the rete ridges have a saw-toothed appearance because they are pointed at their lower ends.

 

The image below shows the HPE of Lichen planus with arrows pointing out Saw toothed appearance of Rete ridges:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The histopathological features of common dermatological conditions, distinguishing between those found in Lichen Planus (Wickham's Striae, Epidermal Acanthosis, Colloid Bodies) and Psoriasis (Munro Micro Abscesses).

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 32.36, 32.38, 34.42, 35.7, 35.8, 37.3, 37.12, 37.14, 37.14

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with lacy lesions in oral cavity and genitals. Her proximal nail fold has extended onto the nail bed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lichen planus

 

Option D.

 

  • Lichen planus is the diagnosis from the clinical scenario given. The skin lesions of LP are purple, flat, polygonal papules.
  • 6Ps : Purple, Pruritic, Polygonal, Plain Topped, Papule, Plaque

 

Lichen Planus:

 

  • The five characteristics of lichen planus lesions are 5Ps: purple polygonal, pruritic, plane topped (flat), and papules.
  • Lichen planus has characteristics including cicatrizing alopecia, flat-topped purple polygonal papules, and plaques on the flexural aspect of the wrist, Wickham's striae on the lips, longitudinal ridging, and thinning of nails.
  • Lichen planus producing Cicatrizing/Scarring alopecia.

 

 

  • In almost 30–70% of cases with lichen planus, mucous membrane lesions develop. It primarily affects the anal and genital mucosa as well as the tongue and buccal mucosa.
  • Wickham's striae are distinctive white streaks that create a lacework in the buccal mucosa.

 

 

 

 

 

  • Dorsal nail pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus.

 

 

  • Puptent sign:

 

 

  • Longitudinal ridging & nail plate thinning

 

 

  • Anonychia:

 

 

  • The image below shows thinning of nail plate (the Most common feature) & longitudinal striations & Trachyonychia –

 

 

Nail Changes in Lichen Planus:

 

  • Up to 10% of Lichen planus cases can involve the nails, but this is usually a minor aspect of the condition.
  • The most distinctive nail change in lichen planus is a dorsal pterygium, which results from the fusion of the proximal nail fold and nail bed.
  • Thinning of the Nail Plate is the most common nail change.
  • Pup Tent Sign – elevation of nail in shape of tent
  • Trachyonychia – 20 nail dystrophy
  • Subungual Hyperkeratosis & onycholysis
  • Longitudinal Melanonychia in Lichen planus of the nail bed
  • Image shows Nails in lichen planus presented with irregular longitudinal grooves & ridges.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris (PRP):

 

  • It is a rare skin disorder that causes skin inflammation and scaling.
  • PRP can sometimes resemble psoriasis, but it's characterized by salmon-colored patches with well-defined borders and areas of spared skin, known as islands of sparing as depicted in the image below.

 

 

Option B. Psoriasis:

 

  • Psoriasis is an autoimmune condition characterized by raised, red, scaly patches on the skin.
  • It can also affect nails (leading to nail pitting, thickening, or separation from the nail bed) but does not produce the specific nail changes described in the question.
  • While psoriasis can involve the genital area, it doesn't produce lacy oral lesions.
  • Hence, this presentation is not typical for psoriasis.

 

Option C. Pityriasis Rosea:

 

  • Pityriasis rosea is a self-limited rash that starts with a single large pink or tan oval area called a "herald patch" followed by the appearance of smaller patches on the torso, often arranged along the lines of skin tension in a “Christmas tree” pattern as depicted in the image below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lichen planus with the characteristic findings of lacy white lesions on mucosal surfaces and specific nail changes.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 37 Page No 37.1-5

choices.text: Collarette Scale - Christmas Tree Pattern - Pityriasis Rosea
Christmas Tree Pattern - Lichen Planus

questions.text: A young male, aged 24, has presented with asymptomatic scaly skin lesions on his back, symmetrically distributed. The provided images showcase the lesions. Can you identify the pattern of these skin lesions & the specific disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Collarette Scale - Christmas Tree Pattern - Pityriasis Rosea

 

Option A.

 

  • Given clinical scenario and images showing Collarette scale (Herald patch) and Christmas tree pattern distributed lesions, points to a diagnosis of Pityriasis rosea.

 

Pityriasis Rosea:

 

  • This is a common skin condition characterized by a heraldpatch, followed by a distinctive, symmetric rash in a Christmas tree pattern.
  • It primarily affects the back and trunk. The rash is often accompanied by a Collarette scale, where the scale is more prominent at the periphery of the lesion.

 

Christmas Tree Pattern:

 

  • The symmetric distribution and orientation of lesions along the lines of skin cleavage on the back is a hallmark of pityriasis rosea.

 

PITYRIASIS ROSEA

 

  • Acute: Self-limiting (6-12 weeks) disease.
  • Etiology: Most common viral trigger is HHV 7.
  • Asymptomatic >> mild pruritus may be present.
  • Features:
  • 1st lesion: Herald patch / mother patch 1-2 weeks later.
  • Secondary lesions: Scaly papules → oval annular plaques → mild pigmentary changes → fades slowly in 6-12 weeks.
  • Distribution of Lesions: Christmas tree pattern (Downwards & outwards from the spine along the lines of Langer).
  • Treatment: Counsel, self-limiting 6-12 weeks.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Wickham’s Striae - Lichen Planus:

 

  • Wickham's striae are fine, white lines found on the surface of papules in lichen planus.
  • Surface of lichen planus lesions seen with oil on top of lesion reveals these whitish linear streaks.

 

 

  • Lichen planus typically presents with pruritic, purplish, polygonal papules and does not exhibit a Christmas tree pattern.

 

Option C. Christmas Tree Pattern - Lichen Planus:

 

  • This is incorrect because, although lichen planus is a common dermatologic condition, it does not present with a Christmas tree pattern. This pattern is specific to pityriasis rosea.

 

Option D. Woronoff Ring – Seborrheic Dermatitis:

 

  • The Woronoff ring is a hypopigmented ring surrounding individual psoriatic lesions. It is usually associated with treatment, most commonly UV radiation or topical steroids.

 

 

  • Seborrheic dermatitis presents with greasy, scaly lesions predominantly on the scalp, face, and upper trunk.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When presented with symmetrically distributed, asymptomatic scaly skin lesions on the back in a young adult, consider pityriasis rosea, particularly if the lesions follow a Christmas tree pattern.
  • This pattern, along with the presence of collarette scaling, is highly suggestive of pityriasis rosea.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page No. 35.8, 37.3, 115.9
